transcript.text: If you export anything for Johnson Controls, you need to strictly comply with the trade requirements. Select each heading to ensure you know what to do.

contentText.text: To comply with trade requirements, you will need to:

instructionText.text: Select each heading. To read the next, click the X to close the text box.
Click on Next (bottom right arrow) to continue.

popText.text:
• Ensure you know which controlled goods, technology, software and services require authorization to be exported, including dual-use items – this helps ensure that these items only go to countries and end users who are authorized to receive them.
  • Strictly follow any authorizations you receive (e.g. identified parties, quantity and value) and hold any business partners to the same standard.

revealCallOut.buttonText: Avoid restricted end users, end uses and destinations

popText.text:
• Ensure you know which trade controls restrict or prohibit exports to which countries, individuals or entities.
  • Find out which end uses are also restricted.
  • Be aware that restricted entities and individuals are identified by governmental agencies on a variety of lists and are typically referred to as “restricted parties”.
  • If you are responsible for conducting restricted party screening, ensure you complete it as required using the Johnson Controls software tool.

revealCallOut.buttonText: Follow regulatory restrictions and Johnson Controls procedures

popText.text:
• Do not engage in any transactions that involve:
    • Iran
    • North Korea
    • Syria
    • Cuba
    • Sudan
    • Crimea Peninsula region of Ukraine*
*As Crimea is not well defined, consult with our trade compliance experts before doing any business with Russia or the Ukraine.

revealCallOut.img: Employee on computer reporting a request to a trade compliance expert
revealCallOut.buttonText: Do not participate in unsanctioned boycotts

popText.text:
• Be aware that restrictive trade requests can be subtle – like being asked to abide by boycotting countries' laws.
  • Restrictive trade requests can be received from anyone, anywhere in the world, so be diligent in your review of business documents, letters of credit and correspondence.
  • If you receive a request that appears to be a restrictive trade request, do not respond to it; instead, report it to a trade compliance expert.
